item.title: A tragedy - part 1
item.description: On the 18th of Dey(January 8th), at 8:30 p.m., the hospital pavilion was filled with the sound of mothers crying and the wail of ambulance sirens. Blood was running across the floor. Precious young people, groaning in pain, were lying on the ground because there weren‚Äôt enough beds. My friend was shouting at the top of his lungs: ‚ÄúMehdi‚Ä¶ Mehdi!‚Äù I couldn‚Äôt answer him. I was in shock. I didn‚Äôt know what I was doing. My hands were starting to go numb. I kept approximating the wound edges to control the bleeding, but my mind was frozen‚Äîalmost as if only my cerebellum was giving orders to my hands. My ears were ringing. I was terrified. I had never seen so many young, innocent lives torn apart like that. As I worked, I kept talking to the boy to make sure he wouldn‚Äôt lose consciousness. His name was Amir‚Äîone of the kind-hearted kids from Sattar Khan. I tried to joke with him to keep him awake. He was sixteen. He said, ‚ÄúIran will be free, doctor.‚Äù I told him, ‚ÄúYes‚Äîabsolutely. That day will come. Don‚Äôt doubt it.‚Äù I tried to move as fast as I could, because there was still so much more to do, and I didn‚Äôt want to put Amir through any more pain than necessary. Suddenly, my friend‚Äîan emergency medicine second-year resident‚Äîcalled out to me. I told Amir, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be right back,‚Äù and ran to the CPR room. A seventeen-year-old girl was brought in, unconscious and intubated. She had taken a hard blow to the front of her chest‚Äîlike blunt trauma from a club or something similar. On the other side, her abdomen and chest were covered with multiple stab wounds. One of the injuries was a sucking chest wound. Her heart rate was dangerously low. I started crying‚Äîhelplessly, uncontrollably‚Äîtears streaming down my face. Through blurred, tear-filled eyes, I quickly applied a three-sided occlusive dressing to the sucking wound, but it was too late. Her rhythm kept dropping, lower and lower, with every passing moment. Someone shouted, ‚ÄúCleaner‚Äîwipe the blood off the floor!‚Äù The cleaner said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve mopped it so many times‚Ä¶ this blood won‚Äôt come off.‚Äù

item.title: # TFCE (Threshold‚ÄëFree Cluster Enhancement) ‚Äî Catching the Real Party in a Giant Hotel
item.description:
Imagine you live in a huge multi‚Äëstory hotel. Hundreds of rooms. Every room has people in it, and every room makes some noise: talking, TV, a door slam, someone laughing, someone dropping a suitcase.

Now here‚Äôs the problem: you step outside the hotel and you hear party noise leaking into the street. You want to answer one question:

Which part of the hotel is actually hosting the real party?

In neuroimaging/EEG terms, each ‚Äúroom‚Äù can be a voxel, an electrode, or a time point‚Äîand the ‚Äúnoise level‚Äù is your test statistic (often a t‚Äëvalue). Your goal is to locate the true effect without getting fooled by random spikes.

item.title: My Linear Model Thinks Getting Older Makes You Poorer (And Other Statistical Tragedies)
item.description:
So there I was, building a wage-prediction model like a responsible data scientist, when my Ridge regression dropped a truth bomb that shattered my worldview: According to my coefficients, every birthday makes you $0.31 poorer per hour.

I immediately canceled my upcoming birthday party and started reverse-aging exercises. Then I remembered: I had fallen into the classic trap of misinterpreting linear model coefficients. Again.

Let me save you from similar existential crises with a lighthearted tour of coefficient interpretation pitfalls‚Äîcomplete with the statistical equivalent of stepping on a Lego barefoot.

item.description:

I‚Äôm a medical doctor and data analyst based in Tehran, Iran. I work at the intersection of clinical medicine and data science, focused on applying AI (machine learning, computer vision, NLP/LLMs, predictive modeling, and explainable AI) to improve decision-making and patient outcomes.

ü§ì My Story Link to heading

My path into medical data science started during my M.D. thesis at Iran University of Medical Sciences, where I studied neuroimaging findings in hospital MRI scans of patients with frontotemporal dementia (FTD) and related them to neuropsychological test scores (e.g., MoCA and MMSE and their subdomains). I worked with routine 1.5T low-resolution 2D clinical MRI data, used slice-to-volume reconstruction methods, and built analysis pipelines using FreeSurfer and SPM. That experience taught me how to handle messy real-world medical data and turn it into evidence.
